Dear Ms. Edmon:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(b) Denial of any essential program service as punishment.
These include, but are not limited to, the following:
(i) Food or creating alternative menus.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth are denied food by staff based on their behaviors. This
included a recent outing where youth went to a hockey game and
not fed.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed on 01/24/2025. No additional
information was provided.
The Program Director was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on
11/26/2024 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the
facility. She remarked she was in the process of updating new
allowance procedures for the facility. Regarding the specific
outing noted in the allegations, the Program Director recalled
youth were not provided their allowance for that instance because
food was provided for them. She stated the outing was for one of
the cottages to go to a local hockey game, and it came together
last minute. She stated the youth went to the game right after
they came back to the facility after school. The Program Director
believed that some of the youth had not gotten a chance to have a
snack prior to leaving. The youth came back from the game at
about 8pm and there was pizza made available for them upon
arriving back to the facility. The Program Director recalled some
confusion if the youth were going to be fed at the game through
the party that donated the tickets. She stated this outing and how
food was handled had nothing to do with the behavior of the
youth.
Youth A was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 11/26/2024
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth A
recalled times when staff said there were no alternatives for what
food was being served but clarified that this was only when snacks
2

or extra food was being provided outside of meals. Youth A
recalled a specific instance where he and Youth C had gone
AWOL together and came back to the facility late at night. Youth
A had missed dinner in the meantime. Youth A stated that food
from dinner was made available, but it was burnt in his
opinion. Youth A recalled Staff 5 not allowing for any alternatives
because it was past normal bedtime.
Youth B was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 11/26/2024
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth B
stated no concerns about food at the facility, he did not believe
that food was ever tied to his behavior. He reported staff had
never taken food away from him or not provided it to him. Youth B
also recalled the hockey game outing and remembered eating
before and after the game when back at the facility.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker
1 on 12/17/2024. Supervisor 1 did not believe food had ever been
withheld from any youth and noted Youth B specifically. He
recalled specific instances when Youth B had gotten upset about
not getting second and third servings of dinner. On one occasion
Youth B wanted a third serving of food and proceeded to stick his
hand in the container, forcing staff to have to throw away that
food. Youth B then took the food out of the trash to attempt to eat
it. Supervisor 1 noted Youth B struggling often in relation to food
but denied that food was ever withheld from him or any other
youth. Supervisor 1 also recalled the hockey game outing as he
was in attendance with them. Supervisor 1 believed some of the
youth had been able to eat prior to the game, and also recalled
pizza being made available for the youth after they returned home.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Staff 1 reported alternative meals were provided to
any youth who did not want to eat a meal served. He also
commented it was common that youth are able to have
seconds. Staff 1 did not believe there were instances where the
provision of food was tied to behavior of the youth at the
facility. Staff 1 stated it was common for Youth B to struggle with
wanting seconds and thirds of food.
Youth C was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Youth C denied witnessing any situations where
youth were denied food or that food was tied to any expected
behavior of youth. Youth C recalled a time when he went AWOL
with Youth A, and when they returned late at night there was
dinner saved for them.
3

Youth D was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Youth D reported never seeing food being withheld
from youth in any form. He stated staff do have to tell youth that
they have been served enough at times, but he never witnessed
staff being mean to the youth about it. Youth D reported going to
the hockey game outing recently and could not recall when he had
eaten prior to or after arriving back at the facility.
Youth E was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Youth E stated there were times when youth missed
meals or food could not be provided to them but it was because of
their own behavior, such as going AWOL and being
unavailable. Youth E reported no concerns on food being
withheld or being used regarding behavior management of
youth. He recalled going to the hockey game outing and
commented that he ate before and after the game.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Staff 2 did not believe there were any instances of
youth not being provided food or having it tied to their
behavior. She remarked that she does most of the cooking for the
youth on her shifts, and always is able to make enough for
seconds for all youth. Staff 2 also noted there are plates set aside
for youth not present at meal times.
Youth F was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Youth F did not believe that food was tied to behavior
at the facility and did not present any concerns related to youth
being fed properly.
Youth G was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. He reported no concern about food at the
facility. Youth G denied there were any connection between youth
being served food and their behaviors.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker
1 on 12/18/2024. Supervisor 2 did not believe there were
instances of youth being denied food based on their behavior. He
has interacted with youth who wanted specific things to eat that
were not available or wanted more to eat prior to everyone getting
their fair share, but Supervisor 2 denied that these instances
occurred when youth were not fed at all. Supervisor 2 also
recalled the recent hockey game outing. He was not in
attendance but recalled there being pizza available for the youth
when they returned from the game.
4

Youth H was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. Youth H did not believe there were any situations
where food was withheld from youth because of their behaviors,
even when youth were escalated or violent or had AWOL’ed and
missed a meal. He also recalled attending the hockey game
outing and stated that the group was served pizza when they
returned to the facility that night.
Youth I was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. Youth I reported no concerns about how food was
served to youth at the facility. He did not believe this was tied to a
youth’s behavior in any way. He stated an example of that was
how food prepared for dinner was often kept to the side for a
youth if they were AWOL and staff did not know when they might
be back to the facility.
Youth J was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. He did not have any concerns about the provision of
food for youth at the facility, and did not believe there was any
connection between food and behavior for the youth.
Youth K was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. He did not have any concerns to report regarding
food and behavior management at the facility.
Youth L was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. He recalled a specific instance when Youth P was
required to “do laps” around the facility’s playground area in order
to get a snack. Youth L believed that it was Staff 6 that had
required this of Youth P.
Youth M was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. He recalled the hockey outing and confirmed that
pizza was served to the youth after they returned from the game.
Youth N was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. Youth N recalled a specific instance where he
believed food was withheld from youth. Staff 7 had told him that
he would be fed, “but you have to do what you need to do to get
it.” Youth N clarified this was referring to cleaning his room. He
further clarified this was about an extra snack after dinner and he
was not being told to clean his room in connection to a regular
meal. Youth N could not recall any other times when he believed
food was being withheld due to the behavior of youth. He also
5

recalled the recent hockey outing and stated that pizza was
served when they arrived home before bedtime.
Youth O was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. He had no concerns to share regarding food at the
facility and did not believe that poor behavior of youth would result
in food not being provided to them. He recalled the hockey outing
and confirmed that he was able to have a snack after school
before going and had pizza when they returned back to the facility.
Youth P was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. Youth P did not express concerns over how food was
handled at the program. He stated meals were always provided
and youth always had enough to eat. Youth P remarked that
some staff like to encourage physical activity of the youth, an
example being youth being told they can get an extra snack if they
walk laps around the facility’s playground area. Youth P recalled
the recent hockey outing where youth were fed pizza upon arriving
back at the facility.
Staff 4 was interviewed over the phone on 01/24/2025. Staff 4
denied that youth were not provided food for any reason, and
clarified that food was not connected to the facility’s behavior
management programming.
Documents reviewed:
• Facility policy & procedure titled “Food policy” last dated
09/26/2021 was provided and reviewed. This policy
contained several statements regarding the relationship
between food and youth behavior:
o “Many of the young people in care at MCHS come
from environments that were characterized by
various forms of deprivation and neglect which
included the use of manipulating or withholding food
to control their behaviors. Therefore, it is imperative
that staff members do not engage in any type of
practices that would recreate or perpetuate the
abuse and neglect.”
o “All food must be served in a desirable fashion, for
example, if a young person is excused due to
behavior while eating cereal, he or she will not be
made to eat soggy cereal.”
o “Staff will not substitute the planned meal with a less
appealing or more appealing meal to control
behavior.”
6

Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed the facility is not
withholding food from youth related to their behaviors.
CONSULTATION:
Consultation was offered to discuss with staff the care needed in
communicating healthy eating habits and the benefits of regular
physical activity to ensure that youth believe staff have their best
interests in mind as opposed to the risk of youth believing that
food may be withheld from them.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention; prohibited
Title restraints; elimination of restraints
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159
Section (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
Description manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the
severity of the youth's behavior, chronological and
developmental age, size, gender, physical condition, medical
condition, psychiatric condition, and personal history, including
any history of trauma, and must be done in a manner
consistent with the youth's treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The physical restraints used by staff are not in alignment with the
training for behavior management used at the facility, including
restraints performed on Youth A in particular.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed on 01/24/2025. No additional
information was provided.
Youth A was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 11/26/2024
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
recalled an instance where Supervisor 1 had to restrain him, and
Youth A believed that Supervisor 1 used a pressure point during
the restraint. Youth A also believed he was on his stomach at one
point during the restraint. Youth A could not provide any more
details on when this occurred or who else was involved.
Youth B was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 11/26/2024
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth B
recalled an instance of an inappropriate restraint, where he saw
7

Staff 4 restraining Youth F outside. During this incident Youth F’s
head was on the ground and Staff 4 was pressing on it. Youth B
recalled hearing Youth F state that he was in pain. He could not
recall any other details on this restraint. Youth B also recalled
seeing Youth A being restrained by a staff while Youth A was on a
bench. Youth B believed this staff was putting his weight on Youth
A’s chest. Youth B could not exactly recall who the staff was but
believed it was Staff 4. Youth B believed this occurred without
anyone else around and could not provide any other details on the
incident.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker
1 on 12/17/2024. Supervisor 1 denied ever participating in a
restraint with Youth A that was performed inappropriately. He
could not recall any situations where he was participating in a
restraint of Youth A and Youth A expressed being in pain, or
where Supervisor 1 put his body weight on Youth A. Supervisor 1
denied the use of any pressure point methods within any
restraints. He commented he generally did not participate in
restraints with Youth A as much as attempt to break up fights and
protect him from other youth. Supervisor 1 believed care was
needed in any physical managements involving Youth A because
of Youth A’s smaller stature.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Staff 1 reported never seeing any inappropriate
restraints and did not believe he had performed any inappropriate
restraints of youth.
Youth C was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. He reported never having seen a restraint that
appeared to be inappropriate or overly physical.
Youth D was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Youth D denied ever seeing staff sit on youth, use
pressure point techniques or any other inappropriate restraint
methods.
Youth E was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Youth E reported no concerns over how restraints
were performed at the facility. He denied ever seeing staff use
chokeholds or putting their bodyweight on youth during a restraint.
Youth F was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. He did not share any concerns about how restraints
occurred at the facility. Youth F did not believe that he was
8

restrained by Staff 4 on any occasions and stated that it was likely
someone else that Youth B may have witnessed.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. She reported never having seen any inappropriate
restraints at the facility, including never seeing staff putting their
weight on top of youth.
Youth G was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Youth G recalled a time when he had to be
restrained. He could not recall which staff was involved or many
details, only that it was a male staff that attempted to hold Youth
G’s arms from behind as Youth G attempted to run away. Youth
G stated he was on his feet for the entirety of this restraint. He did
not have any concerns to report about how youth were restrained
at the facility.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker
1 on 12/18/2024. He reported never witnessing a restraint where a
youth was pinned to the ground or had the weight of a staff on
them. Supervisor 2 specifically stated that he had not participated
in any restraints with Youth A.
Youth H, Youth I, Youth J, Youth K, Youth N, and Youth O
were interviewed separately over the phone with DHHS Worker 1
on 12/18/2024. None of the youth reported any concerns about
the way restraints were implemented at the facility.
Youth M was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. Youth M recalled a restraint where he felt like his
face was pushed into a couch cushion. He recalled struggling
against the restraint as it occurred but believed that this was not a
proper technique for a restraint. Youth M did not want to state
who the staff involved was and did not have any other details to
provide.
Youth P was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. Youth P described one incident where he believed a
youth was not restrained properly. The incident he described was
investigated by DCWL through Special Investigation
#2025SIC0000077.
Staff 4 was interviewed over the phone on 01/24/2025. Staff 4
believed restraints occurred as best they could at the facility. He
denied ever participating in a restraint with Youth A or Youth F
where they ended up on the ground or were in any sort of position
9

where they could get injured. Staff 4 stated restraints tended to
be short in terms of duration, and many of the youth in the
program were younger and smaller and their behavior could be
managed without having to go hands on.
Documents reviewed:
• Facility policy titled “Crisis Prevention Institution -
Nonviolent Crisis Intervention” last revised 09/01/2024 was
reviewed. This policy instructed staff to use the trained
restraint model as an intervention for specific reasons
including “physical aggression toward another person.”
• Facility policy titled “Physical Intervention” last revised
09/01/2024 was reviewed. This policy and procedure
provided staff with requirements to be followed during a
restraint, including never placing weight on a youth’s chest
or back and never hitting or kicking a youth.
• Facility incident reports pertaining to the restraints of Youth
A and Youth F were reviewed. There were no restraint
incidents that matched what was provided in interviews and
no other concerns were noted within the documentation.
• Staff 4’s personnel record was provided and reviewed. His
employment was terminated on 11/20/2024. He had two
disciplinary actions noted in his file, one from 05/08/2024
regarding the use of personal phones while supervising
youth. The second action occurred on 07/15/2024 for
insubordination regarding AWOL policies and for having
contact with a youth while being instructed not to do so
during an investigation. At the time of his employment
ending Staff 4 was current on facility de-escalation and
physical management training.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed staff are performing
restraints in a safe and trained manner.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited
to:
10

(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Supervisors have instructed direct care staff to hit the minor
children back if they hit the staff first.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed on 01/24/2025. No additional
information was provided.
The Program Director was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on
11/26/2024 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the
facility. She stated she has never instructed staff to hit a youth,
has never witnessed other staff doing this and has not had this
reported to her by youth or staff.
Youth A was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 11/26/2024
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth A
believed that other youth have encouraged youth to hit staff, but
he denied ever hearing staff state the same to any youth.
Youth B was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 11/26/2024
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth B
recalled hearing Staff 4 say to a youth he could not recall, “Go
ahead, hit his ass back.” This was in reference to one youth
hitting another. Youth B could not recall any other details about
this anecdote.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker
1 on 12/17/2024. He denied ever instructing staff to hit any youth,
and did not believe he had ever witnessed any staff doing the
same.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. He had never heard of staff encouraging anyone to
hit anyone.
Youth E was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Youth E reported never seeing or hearing of a staff
member encouraging staff to hit youth or encouraging youth to hit
youth.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. She denied ever hearing staff instruct youth to hit
someone else. Staff 2 noted brief experiences working with Staff
11

4 because he usually worked a different shift, but she believed he
had mentioned recently having to be “hands off” with any youth
because of concerns over his past physical managements.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker
1 on 12/18/2024. He denied ever hearing staff encouraging other
staff or youth to hit one another.
Youth H, Youth I, Youth J, Youth K, Youth N, Youth O, and
Youth P were interviewed separately over the phone with DHHS
Worker 1 on 12/18/2024. They all reported lack of concern about
staff encouraging youth or other staff to hit each other.
Staff 4 was interviewed over the phone on 01/24/2025. Staff 4
denied ever encouraging anyone to hit a youth while working at
the program.
Documents reviewed:
• Facility policy titled “Physical Intervention” last revised
09/01/2024 was reviewed. This policy and procedure
provided staff with requirements to be followed during a
restraint, including never placing weight on a youth’s chest
or back and never hitting or kicking a youth.
• Facility incident reports pertaining to the restraints of Youth
A and Youth F were reviewed. There were no restraint
incidents that matched what was provided in allegations or
interviews and no other concerns were noted within the
documentation.
• Staff 4’s personnel record was provided and reviewed. His
employment was terminated on 11/20/2024. He had two
disciplinary actions noted in his file, one from 05/08/2024
regarding the use of personal phones while supervising
youth. The second action occurred on 07/15/2024 for
insubordination regarding AWOL policies and for having
contact with a youth while being instructed not to do so
during an investigation. At the time of his employment
ending Staff 4 was current on facility de-escalation and
physical management training.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed staff are not encouraging
youth be hit by staff or other youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
12

Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited
to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to
a youth's background or appearance or mental state.
Yelling, threats, ridicule, or humiliation are strictly
prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are regularly verbally abusive towards youth.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed on 01/24/2025. He recalled
hearing Supervisor 1 state “You’re a honky, you’re white trash” to
a youth who he could not recall. The complainant also noted he
heard Staff 4 use swear words and inappropriate language with
the youth on a regular basis.
The Program Director was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on
11/26/2024 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the
facility. She denied ever swearing at youth or speaking to anyone
in a derogatory manner, and denied seeing any staff do the same.
Youth A was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 11/26/2024
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth A
stated it was common place for staff to swear at youth when they
were interacting. He could not recall any specific times this
occurred, but named Staff 4 and Supervisor 1 as staff that
regularly used swear words when interacting with the youth.
Youth B was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 11/26/2024
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. While
discussing allegations related to food, Youth B recalled was one
instance when Staff 4 responded to him “Fuck no” when Youth B
was trying to get seconds from dinner. Youth B was not sure if
anyone else heard this as he and Staff 4 were standing in the
kitchen of the cottage. Youth B stated he also heard Staff 4
remark “You are a fat ass” on one occasion while Youth B was in
his room, and Youth B believed this was directed at himself.
13

Supervisor 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker
1 on 12/17/2024. Supervisor 1 denied ever using any
disrespectful or derogatory language towards youth. He also
denied hearing other staff do the same towards youth.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. He denied ever swearing at youth or using any
derogatory language towards youth. Staff 1 also denied ever
hearing other staff do the same.
Youth C was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Youth C stated that there had been times that Staff 4
had made negative comments to him about his weight, both in and
around meal times. Youth C recalled these comments hurting his
feelings when he heard them. He did not have any other specific
information or names of staff to report.
Youth D was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Youth D reported hearing staff use swear words
when interacting with youth “all the time.” He declined to name
any specific staff. Youth D reported hearing a youth that he could
not recall use a racial slur and a staff used the same slur back to
the youth. In addition, Youth D recalled a third shift staff that he
could not recall stating “I’m going to beat your ass” to Youth F, but
could not recall any other details regarding this.
Youth E was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Youth E stated that there have been staff who use
swear words when interacting with youth, sometimes when the
youth are escalated and swearing also and sometimes without
behavior from the other youth. Youth E could not report any
specific names or instances of when he witnessed this.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Staff 2 denied ever using derogatory or inappropriate
language with youth. She did not believe any other staff spoke in
that manner as well.
Youth F was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/17/2024. Youth F stated staff had used swear words in
interactions with him. He could not recall any specific staff or
specific instances when this had occurred.
14

Supervisor 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker
1 on 12/18/2024. He denied ever hearing any staff use swear
words or other disparaging language when interacting with youth.
Youth H, Youth I, Youth J, Youth K, and Youth O were
interviewed separately over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. All of the youth did not have any concerns to report
about the language used by staff or how they were treated
verbally by staff.
Youth L was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
12/18/2024. Youth L recalled hearing Staff 2 remark to Youth M
and Youth P that they needed to “sit their fat ass down” during
dinner time on one occasion. Youth L could not recall any other
